text: بسم الله الرحمن الرّحيم المقدمة إن الحمد لله، نحمده، ونستعينه، ونستغفره، ونعوذ بالله من شرور أنفسنا، وسيئات أعمالنا، من يهد الله فلا مضلّ له، ومن يضلل فلا هادي له، وأشهد أن لا إله إلا الله وحده لا شريك له، وأشهد أن محمدا عبده ورسوله. {يا أَيُّهَا الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا اِتَّقُوا اللهَ حَقَّ تُقاتِهِ وَلا تَمُوتُنَّ إِلاّ وَأَنْتُمْ مُسْلِمُونَ} [آل عمران:102] {يا أَيُّهَا النّاسُ اِتَّقُوا رَبَّكُمُ الَّذِي خَلَقَكُمْ مِنْ نَفْسٍ واحِدَةٍ وَخَلَقَ مِنْها زَوْجَها وَبَثَّ مِنْهُما رِجالاً كَثِيراً وَنِساءً وَاِتَّقُوا اللهَ الَّذِي تَسائَلُونَ بِهِ وَالْأَرْحامَ إِنَّ اللهَ كانَ عَلَيْكُمْ رَقِيباً} [النساء:1] {يا أَيُّهَا الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا اِتَّقُوا اللهَ وَقُولُوا قَوْلاً سَدِيداً (70) يُصْلِحْ لَكُمْ أَعْمالَكُمْ وَيَغْفِرْ لَكُمْ ذُنُوبَكُمْ وَمَنْ يُطِعِ اللهَ وَرَسُولَهُ فَقَدْ فازَ فَوْزاً عَظِيماً} [الأحزاب:70 - 71] أما بعد: فإن أصدق الحديث كتاب الله، وأحسن الهدي هدي محمد صلى الله عليه وسلم، وشرّ الأمور محدثاتها، وكلّ محدثة بدعة، وكلّ بدعة ضلالة، وكلّ ضلالة في النار.
text_en:
In the Name of Allah, the Most Merciful, the Most Compassionate. Introduction: All praise is due to Allah. We praise Him, seek His help, and ask His forgiveness. We seek refuge in Allah from the evils of ourselves and the misdeeds of our actions. Whomever Allah guides, none can mislead; and whomever He allows to stray, none can guide. I bear witness that there is no god but Allah alone without partner, and I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and messenger. 

{O you who believe! Fear Allah as He should be feared, and do not die except as Muslims} [Āl ‘Imrān: 102]. 

{O mankind! Fear your Lord who created you from a single soul, and created from it its mate, and spread from both many men and women. And fear Allah, through whom you ask one another, and the wombs; surely Allah is ever watching over you} [An-Nisā’: 1]. 

{O you who believe! Fear Allah and speak words of appropriate justice. He will rectify your deeds for you and forgive your sins. And whoever obeys Allah and His Messenger has certainly achieved a great triumph} [Al-Aḥzāb: 70–71]. 

To proceed: The truest speech is the Book of Allah, and the best guidance is the guidance of Muhammad (peace be upon him). The worst of matters are newly invented ones; every innovation is a misguidance, and every misguidance is in the Fire.

text:
This is one of the books of Sheikh Imam Izz al-Din Muhammad bin Abi Bakr bin Abd al-Aziz bin Muhammad bin Jama'ah, the scholar of the Egyptian lands in rational sciences of his time. He addressed the Prophetic Biography in a gentle and concise style, where he said in his introduction: 'This is a small-sized book, precious in knowledge, containing important aspects of the biography of our master Muhammad, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and I named it: "Al-Ghurar wa Al-Durar fi Sirat Khayr Al-Bashar"' (1). I present it to the Islamic library as a service to the true religion. I have verified it and made a comprehensive biography for the author introducing him. I exerted my effort, energy, and capability in producing the book in the best form. Whatever correctness is in it, is from the guidance of the Most Merciful, and whatever error is in it, is from me, and Exalted is He who possesses perfection. I hope from Allah - Glory be to Him and Exalted - that I have been successful in that, for He is the best to be asked and the best to answer.
Adnan Abu Zaid

Author's Biography

1 - His Name and Lineage:
Muhammad bin Abi Bakr bin Abd al-Aziz bin Muhammad bin Ibrahim bin Sa'd Allah bin Jama'ah bin Muhammad bin Ali bin Hazim bin Sakhr bin Abdullah, Izz al-Din, Abu Abdullah son of Sheikh Shams al-Din son of Chief Judge Izz al-Din son of Chief Judge Badr al-Din, Al-Kinani, originally from Hama, Egyptian, Shafi'i.

2 - His Birth and Family:
Our translator (biographee) Al-Izz was born in the year seven hundred and forty-nine in the city of Yanbu, which is a city on the coast of the Red Sea on the side of the Arabian Peninsula (1).
Biographical dictionaries paid great attention to the family of Al Jama'ah, because it is one of the large scientific families that produced many unique scholars who served the true religion. Their presence was not limited to a specific country over another; rather, we find them in Sham (Levant), Jerusalem, Mecca, and Cairo. Among them:

Here are some notables of this family:
1 - Chief Judge Badr al-Din Muhammad bin Ibrahim bin Sa'd Allah bin Jama'ah Al-Kinani, born in Hama, Shafi'i. He heard much, taught, issued fatwas, and authored. He combined judgeship and preaching in Jerusalem and the Umayyad Mosque, and the position of Sheikh of Sheikhs. Leadership ended up with him in his time, along with his piety, devoutness, and integrity. He died in the year (733 AH) (1).
2 - Chief Judge Izz al-Din Abd al-Aziz bin Muhammad bin Ibrahim bin Sa'd Allah bin Jama'ah, Al-Kinani, born in Damascus, Egyptian, Shafi'i. He grew up in a house of knowledge and dignity. He heard and read much, and his sheikhs by hearing and authorization exceed one thousand three hundred. He sat for teaching at the age of fourteen. He narrated hadith, issued fatwas, and authored. He performed Hajj and stayed in Mecca (Mujawarah) frequently. He used to wish to die in one of the Two Holy Sanctuaries removed from judgeship, and he attained that, dying as a pilgrim in the year (767 AH) (2).

Add to that the natural aptitude he enjoyed, along with what Allah Almighty endowed him with of care and success, without which guidance is not complete. So he desired knowledge and its acquisition, and the love of its people, after he tasted its sweetness, until he reached the high ambition he reached. He would not look at anything without wanting to stand on its origin and participate in it. May Allah Almighty have mercy on the ascetic Sheikh Muhammad bin al-Fadl al-Balkhi when he said: "Whoever tastes the sweetness of knowledge cannot be patient from it" (1).
So he grew up occupied with knowledge, and heard much from a group of senior scholars. He heard from Al-Qalanisi, Al-'Aradi, Al-Tabbani, his grandfather Abd al-Aziz, and others. He attended Al-Maydumi, and a group of Levantines and Egyptians granted him Ijazah through the care of Sheikh Zain al-Din Al-Iraqi. He studied jurisprudence with Sheikh Siraj al-Din Al-Bulqini.
Then he inclined towards rational sciences, so he read under the scholars of logic in his time, such as Al-Sirami, Al-Izz Al-Razi, and Ibn Khaldun, until he mastered this science, and became pointed out with fingertips (famous), and students sought him from every direction, and he became a nation by himself in it.
In the later part of his life, he turned to looking into books of Hadith. He borrowed from Ibn al-Adim "Takhrij Ahadith Al-Rafi'i Al-Kabir" by Sheikh Ibn al-Mulaqqin, which is in seven volumes. He went through all of it, summarized it, and finished it...

His student Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar said (1): He did not marry as far as I knew, but he had his father's wife, so she used to manage his house affairs, and he was dutiful to her and kind to her. It did not happen that he performed Hajj, despite his companions' eagerness for him to do so. He was criticized for dressing in the Persian style with a long mustache and lack of Siwak (tooth stick), until his teeth fell out.

6 - Scholars' Praise of Him:
He reached such high ambition that Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar reports to us (2) saying: He inclined to rational sciences; so he mastered them, until he became a nation by himself, and all the students of the country remained dependent on him in that. He authored many widespread works, and for every book he taught - even though he almost taught all these summaries - he had a work, two works, or three, ranging from margin notes (Hashiyah), points (Nukat), and explanation (Sharh). He was the wonder of his age in good presentation.
Ibn Qadi Shuhbah mentioned (3): He was a sign among signs in knowing literary and rational sciences, and the two principles (Usul al-Fiqh and Usul al-Din). Most people of Egypt took from him.

7 - His Works:
The majority of his scientific works that he authored were explanations, points, and summaries of books he taught to students. He enjoyed a keen mind and broad understanding, so you see him writing on a single book three works, ranging from margin notes, explanation, or points. He was the wonder of his age in good presentation, but he was not gifted with the faculty or happiness in good authorship. It appears: That he intended by them to remember what he wanted to deliver and present; therefore, there was between them (his writing and speaking) as between the earth and the Pleiades (huge difference). Rather, there was between his pen and his tongue as between him and individual students of his. He authored many works: religious, literary, technical, and other sciences prevalent in his era. They exceed two hundred works, varied in twenty arts. He collected them in a single volume, and most of them were lost at the hands of students, as reported by Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar (1), Ibn Qadi Shuhbah (2), and Al-Sakhawi (3).

Therefore, it was more eloquent than Mahmoud; for Mahmoud is from the triliteral simple verb, and Muhammad is from the doubled verb; for exaggeration, so he is the one who is praised more than others among humans are praised; and for this reason - and Allah knows best - he was named so in the Torah; due to the many praiseworthy qualities by which he, his religion, and his nation were described in the Torah, until Moses - peace be upon him - wished to be among them".

Allah sent him to mankind entirely while his age was forty years (2), and it was said: and ten days, and it was said: and two months, and it was said: forty-three years. The people of Mecca besieged him in the Shi'b (ravine); he stayed less than three [years], and came out of the siege while he was forty-nine years old. He migrated from Mecca to Medina while he was fifty-three years old, and it was said: five, and it was said: fifty, on Monday of Rabi' al-Awwal, and it was said: it was in Safar. He entered Medina (4) on Monday, twelve nights having passed... . . . . . . .

foot_note: 1. = Urwa bin al-Zubayr, then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, met Al-Zubayr in a caravan of Muslims who were merchants returning from Sham. Al-Zubayr clothed the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and Abu Bakr in white clothes. The Muslims in Medina heard of the departure of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, from Mecca. They used to go out every morning to the Harrah (volcanic field) waiting for him until the midday heat turned them back. One day they returned after waiting long; when they reached their houses, a man from the Jews climbed one of their forts for something he was looking at; he saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and his companions dressed in white, the mirage disappearing by them. The Jew could not help but shout at the top of his voice: O assembly of Arabs! This is your luck/grandfather whom you wait for. The Muslims rushed to weapons; they met the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, at the back of the Harrah. He turned with them to the right until he camped with them in Banu Amr bin Auf. That was on Monday of the month of Rabi' al-Awwal. Abu Bakr stood for the people, and the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, sat silent. Those of the Ansar who came and had not seen the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, began greeting Abu Bakr, until the sun hit the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. Abu Bakr came and shaded him with his cloak. So the people recognized the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, from that. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, stayed in Banu Amr bin Auf for ten-odd nights, and established the mosque that was founded on piety, and the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, prayed in it. Then he rode his mount, and proceeded with people walking with him, until it kneeled at the mosque of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, in Medina, where some Muslim men were praying that day. It was a place for drying dates belonging to Suhayl and Sahl, two orphan boys under the care of As'ad bin Zurarah. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said when his mount kneeled with him: "This, if Allah wills, is the place." Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, called the two boys and bargained with them for the drying place to take it as a mosque. They said: No, rather we gift it to you, O Messenger of Allah. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, refused to accept it from them as a gift until he bought it from them. Then he built it as a mosque. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, started moving bricks with them in its building, saying while moving bricks: "This load is not the load of Khaybar, this is more righteous to our Lord and purer", and saying: "O Allah, indeed the reward is the reward of the Hereafter, so have mercy on the Ansar and the Muhajirah." If you kill, you kill one with blood (avenged), if you are gracious, you are gracious to a grateful one, if you want money, ask from it what you wish. He was left until the next day. Then he said to him: «What do you have, O Thumamah?» He said: What I told you: If you are gracious, you are gracious to a grateful one. He left him until the day after. He said: «What do you have, O Thumamah?» He said: I have what I told you. He said: «Release Thumamah». He went to a palm grove near the mosque, washed, then entered the mosque and said: I bear witness that there is no god but Allah, and I bear witness that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah. O Muhammad! By Allah! There was no face on earth more hateful to me than your face, so your face became the most beloved of faces to me. By Allah! There was no religion more hateful to me than your religion, so your religion became the most beloved religion to me. By Allah! There was no land more hateful to me than your land, so your land became the most beloved land to me. Your cavalry took me while I wanted Umrah, so what do you see? The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, gave him glad tidings, and ordered him to perform Umrah. When he arrived in Mecca, someone said to him: You apostatized (Sabuta). He said: No, but I embraced Islam with Muhammad, Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. No, by Allah, not a grain of wheat will come to you from Yamama until the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, permits it».

text:
And he had a helmet of iron, crushed on his honorable head on the day of Uhud, and another. And a baton called: Al-Arjun. And a rod of Shawhat called: Al-Mamshuq (1). And a Hirawah, which is: The Staff.
And a black banner called: Al-Uqab. And white flags (2), and perhaps black was put in it. Perhaps they were from the headcovers of his wives - may Allah be pleased with them. And a dusty flag. It was narrated from the Hadith of Ibn Abbas (3): That written on his banner: La ilaha illa Allah Muhammadun Rasulullah.
foot_note:
1. See "Sirat Ibn Kathir" (715/ 4), and "Subul al-Huda wa al-Rashad" (114/ 6), he said: "Shawhat: with Fatha on dotted Shin, Sukun on Waw, Fatha on Ha and undotted Ta, a type of mountain tree from which bows are made". See: "Al-Nihaya" by Ibn Al-Athir (508/ 2). 
2. Ibn Majah extracted in his "Sunan" (914/ 2) with Hasan chain, from Ibn Abbas, said: The banner of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was black, and his flag white. 
3. The Hadith extracted by Ibn Adi in "Al-Kamil fi Du'afa' Al-Rijal" (240/ 2), in biography of: Hammad bin Abi Hamid, who is Muhammad bin Abi Hamid, and said: Hammad is a nickname, Abu Ibrahim Al-Zuraqi Al-Ansari Al-Madani. He quoted Yahya bin Ma'in saying: His hadith is nothing. Also quoted Al-Bukhari saying: Munkar al-Hadith. Ibn Hajar said in "Al-Fath" (127/ 6): And for Abu Al-Sheikh from hadith of Ibn Abbas: Written on his banner was: La ilaha illa Allah Muhammadun Rasulullah, and its chain is weak. Indicated by author saying: Yurowa (It is narrated); i.e., conveyed in weak form.

text:
37 - His Clothing, peace and blessings be upon him:
He had a turban called: Al-Sahab; he clothed Ali with it (1). And his Rida' (cloak) called: Al-Fath, he entered the Day of Conquest (2) wearing a black turban, and preached like that. He used to hang his turban between his shoulders, turn it, and tuck it behind him. From Anas (3): His shirt was cotton, short in length, short-sleeved. From Jabir (4): He used to wear his red Burd (cloak) on the two Eids, and Friday. He, peace and blessings be upon him, had a cloth he wiped with when he performed ablution (5). He had two green Burds, a black Kisa', a waist-wrapper (Izar) five spans long, and a saffron-dyed quilt. The most beloved clothes to him: The shirt (Qamis), white clothes, and Hibarah (striped Yemeni cloth).
foot_note:
1. Ibn al-Qayyim said in "Zad al-Ma'ad" (135/ 1): "He had a turban called: Al-Sahab, he clothed Ali with it. He used to wear it, and wear a cap (Qalansuwah) under it. He used to wear a cap without a turban, and wear a turban without a cap. When he turbaned, he hung his turban between his shoulders". 
2. See: "Sahih Muslim" (990/ 2). 
3. Extracted by: Ibn Sa'd in his "Tabaqat" (458/ 1). 
4. Extracted by: Ibn Sa'd in his "Tabaqat" (451/ 1). 
5. Al-Tirmidhi (74/ 1) extracted from Aisha - may Allah be pleased with her, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, had a cloth he dried with after ablution. He said after it: Aisha's hadith is not established, and nothing authentic from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, exists on this subject.

text:
He wore at a time a Jubbah with tight sleeves (1), and at a time: a Qaba' (outer garment). He took a ring of silver, its stone from it, its engraving: Muhammad Rasulullah; he wore it on the right little finger, and perhaps on the left, putting the stone towards the palm (2). Postscript: Engraving of Abu Bakr's ring: Ni'ma Al-Qadir Allah. Umar: Idhkur Al-Mawt Ya Umar. Uthman: Billah Al-Azim. Ali: Allah Al-Malik. Muawiyah and his son Yazid: La Quwwata Illa Billah. Umar bin Abd al-Aziz: Umar Yu'minu Billah Mukhlisan, said Al-Kalbi.
Al-Najashi gifted him two plain black leather socks (Khuffayn); he wore them and wiped over them. He had four pairs of Khuffs obtained from Khaybar. He had two Sa'diyyah sandals. A mattress of leather stuffed with palm fiber. Hafsa was asked: What was the mattress of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him? She said: A sackcloth we folded twice, and he slept on it. And he prayed. He, peace and blessings be upon him, had a tent called: Al-Kinn. A cup called: Al-Rayyan. And another chained. A stone vessel called: Al-Mikhdab. And a brass vessel
foot_note:
1. It is: A Levantine Jubbah he, peace and blessings be upon him, used to wear in his travels as Al-Bukhari (2185/ 5) and Muslim (229/ 1) transmitted from him. 
2. See: "Al-Bukhari" (2203/ 5), and "Muslim" (1656/ 3).

containing henna. A water skin called: Al-Sadirah. An oil container. A comb of ivory, it was said: It is Al-Dabl. A Kohl container. Scissors. Siwak. A bowl called: Al-Ghabra', carried by four. A Sa' (measure). A Mudd (measure). A velvet cloth. A bed whose legs were of teak.

* From Horses:
1 - Al-Sakb (1), the first horse he owned (2).

3 - And Al-Lahif (4).

foot_note:
1. Likened to pouring water and its flow, for its speed. 
2. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, bought it from a Bedouin for ten Uqiyyahs. It was called: Al-Daris, so the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, changed it; it was the first he raided upon at Uhud. The Muslims had no horse that day other than it, and a horse for Abu Burdah bin Niyar. See: "Ansab al-Ashraf" (509/ 1), and "Tabaqat Ibn Sa'd" (489/ 1). 
3. Ibn Sayyid al-Nas said (409/ 1): Named so for the beauty of its neighing, as if reciting Rajaz poetry. 
4. In "Al-Bukhari" (1049/ 3), from hadith of Abbas bin Sahl, from his father, from his grandfather, said: Then the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, had a horse in our garden called: Al-Lahif. Abu Abdullah said: Some said: Al-Lakhif; i.e., with Kha.

As Muslim extracted in his "Sahih" (1398/ 3): From Al-Abbas - may Allah be pleased with him, said: "I witnessed with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, the day of Hunayn. I and Abu Sufyan bin Al-Harith bin Abd al-Muttalib stuck to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and did not leave him. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was on a white mule of his gifted to him by Farwah bin Nufathah Al-Judhami. When Muslims and disbelievers met; Muslims turned fleeing. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, started spurring his mule towards the disbelievers. Al-Abbas said: I was holding the bridle of the Messenger of Allah's mule,-

foot_note:
1. = holding it back so it wouldn't speed up, and Abu Sufyan holding the stirrup of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: «O Abbas! Call the people of Al-Samurah (Tree)». Abbas said - and he was a loud-voiced man - so I said at the top of my voice: Where are the people of Al-Samurah? He said: By Allah! It was as if their turning when they heard my voice was the turning of cows to their calves. They said: Ya Labbayk Ya Labbayk. He said: They fought the disbelievers. The call was among the Ansar saying: O Assembly of Ansar! O Assembly of Ansar! He said: Then the call was restricted to Banu Al-Harith bin Al-Khazraj, saying: O Banu Al-Harith bin Al-Khazraj! O Banu Al-Harith bin Al-Khazraj! The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, looked while on his mule stretching up on it towards their fighting. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: «This is when the oven heated up (battle intensified)». He said: Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, took pebbles; and threw them at the faces of the disbelievers, then said: «Be defeated by the Lord of Muhammad». He said: I went to look; and the fighting was as it was, as I saw. He said: By Allah! It was only that he threw them with his pebbles; that I kept seeing their edge blunted, and their affair retreating». 
1. See: "Tabaqat Ibn Sa'd" (491/ 1), and "Tarikh al-Tabari" (141/ 2).

book_title: Al-Ghurar wa Al-Durar fi Sirat Khayr Al-Bashar (The Blazes and Pearls in the Biography of the Best of Mankind), may Allah bless him and grant him peace
text:
On other than her. He bought her for four hundred dirhams (1). She is Al-Qaswa'.
2 - And Al-Jad'a', she is the one that was outraced. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: «It is a right upon Allah that He does not raise anything of this world except He lowers it» (2). It was said: The outraced one is another. It was said: They are three.
3 - And he, peace and blessings be upon him, stood in the Farewell Hajj on a red camel.
4 - And he had a camel called: Al-Tha'lab (3). A camel was gifted to him on the day of Hudaybiyah (4).
He had twenty milk-camels (Liqhah) (5), tended by Yasar at Dhu Al-Jadar (6),
foot_note:
1. In "Ansab al-Ashraf" (511/ 1): "Abu Bakr - may Allah be pleased with him - bought it for four hundred dirhams, and the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, took it from him for that price. It is established that he gifted it, and he accepted, and migrated on it". 
2. Extracted by Al-Bukhari in "His Sahih" (1053/ 3), Al-Nasa'i (227/ 6), Abu Ya'la in "His Musnad" (90/ 6), Al-Bayhaqi in "Al-Kubra" (16/ 10), all from the hadith of Anas, with it. The she-camel that was outraced: Is Al-Adba' as they mentioned, not Al-Jad'a', as the author mentioned. 
3. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, sent Kharash bin Umayyah to Quraysh on the day of Hudaybiyah on this camel. Quraysh harmed him and hamstrung his camel. See: "Al-Isti'ab" by Ibn Abd al-Barr (445/ 2). 
4. Abu Dawood extracted in his "Sunan" (145/ 2) from Ibn Abbas - may Allah be pleased with him: That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him: gifted in the year of Hudaybiyah among the sacrificial animals of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, a camel that belonged to Abu Jahl with a silver nose ring in its head, angering thereby the polytheists, gained by the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, on the day of Badr. 
5. See: "Tabaqat Ibn Sa'd" (495/ 1), and "Sirat Ibn Sayyid al-Nas" (411/ 2). 
6. Written in original: "Al-Jadal", which is a mistake. What I established is correct. Dhu Al-Jadar-

And seven milk-camels at Dhu Al-Jadar also, and a milk-camel named: Marwah. And a hundred sheep (1), and a sheep called: Ghawthah, and it was said: Ghaythah, and a sheep called: Qamar. And a goat called: Al-Yaman, and seven Manaih (milk-goats lent for milking) tended by Umm Ayman, and a white rooster.

39 - His Death, peace and blessings be upon him:
The pain he died of started in the house of Maymunah (2), and it was said: in the house of
foot_note:
1. = is: Sheep pasture six miles from Medina, in the area of Quba. Said by Al-Salihi in "Subul al-Huda wa al-Rashad" (30/ 6). 
1. Imams Ahmad (211/ 4) and Abu Dawood (35/ 1) extracted from Laqit bin Sabrah, said: I was the delegate of Banu Al-Muntafiq, or in the delegation of Banu Al-Muntafiq to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. He said: When we came to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, we did not find him in his house, and met Aisha Mother of Believers. He said: She ordered Khazirah (meat soup) for us, so it was made for us. He said: And we were brought a Qina', and Qutayba did not say: Al-Qina', and Al-Qina' is the tray with dates. Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, came and said: «Did you get anything? Or was anything ordered for you?». He said: We said: Yes, O Messenger of Allah. He said: While we were sitting with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, the shepherd drove his sheep to the pen, and with him was a bleating kid. He said: «What did she give birth to, O so-and-so?». He said: A female kid. He said: «Slaughter a sheep for us in its place». Then he said: «Do not think, and he did not say La tahsabanna, that we slaughtered it for your sake. We have a hundred sheep we do not want to increase. So if the shepherd brings a female kid, we slaughter a sheep in its place». See: "Sirat Ibn Sayyid al-Nas" (411/ 2). 
2. This is narrated in the Sahih as Muslim extracted (312/ 1), from Aisha - may Allah be pleased with her, said: Then the first the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, complained (of illness) was in the house of Maymunah.

book_title: Al-Ghurar wa Al-Durar fi Sirat Khayr Al-Bashar (The Blazes and Pearls in the Biography of the Best of Mankind), may Allah bless him and grant him peace
text: Zainab bint Jahsh, and it was said: in the house of Rayhanah. He asked permission of his wives to be nursed in the house of Aisha (1); they permitted him. His pain intensified, so he said: «Indeed I suffer pain as two men of you suffer» (2); to increase his reward. When death attended him, he started wiping his face with water, saying: «O Allah help me against the stupors of death» (3). Allah gave him choice; he chose meeting Him. He passed away, peace and blessings be upon him, leaning on Aisha's chest, being sixty-three years old (4), and it was said:
foot_note:
1. Al-Bukhari (914/ 2) and Muslim (312/ 1) mentioned that in "Their Sahihs": Aisha - may Allah be pleased with her - said: Then when the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, became heavy, and his pain intensified; he asked permission of his wives to be nursed in my house. They permitted him. So he went out between two men, his feet dragging on the ground. 
2. Al-Bukhari (2143/ 5) and Muslim (1991/ 4) extracted in "Their Sahihs" from Abdullah bin Mas'ud - may Allah be pleased with him, said: I entered upon the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, while he was suffering severe pain; I touched him with my hand, and said: O Messenger of Allah! You are suffering severe pain. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: «Yes, I suffer as two men of you suffer». I said: Is that because you have double reward? The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: «Yes». Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: «No Muslim is afflicted by harm or illness, or other than that, but Allah sheds his sins from him as the tree sheds its leaves». 
3. Al-Bukhari extracted in his "Sahih" (2387/ 5) from Aisha - may Allah be pleased with her, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, had before him a Rakwah, or a box containing water. He started putting his hand in the water, wiping his face with it, saying: «There is no god but Allah, indeed death has stupors». Then he raised his hand, and started saying: «In the Highest Companionship», until he passed away, and his hand fell. Abu Abdullah said: The box is of wood, and the Rakwah is of leather. 
4. This is the correct view, as Al-Bukhari (1300/ 3), (1416/ 3), and Muslim (1825/ 4), (1826/ 4), (1827/ 4) extracted in "Their Sahihs" from hadith of Aisha, Ibn Abbas, Muawiyah, and Anas - may Allah be pleased with them all.

book_title: Al-Ghurar wa Al-Durar fi Sirat Khayr Al-Bashar (The Blazes and Pearls in the Biography of the Best of Mankind), may Allah bless him and grant him peace
text: Sixty-five, and it was said: sixty. He was covered with a Burd. It was said: Angels covered him, and came for condolence; heard but not seen: Peace be upon you O People of the House and Allah's mercy and blessings. Every soul shall taste death, and you will only be given your full compensation on the Day of Resurrection. Indeed in Allah is consolation for every calamity, compensation for every deceased, and attainment for everything missed; so in Allah trust, and in Him hope; for the afflicted one is deprived of reward. Peace be upon you and Allah's mercy and blessings. They used to think this condolence was from Al-Khidr (1) peace be upon him. He was washed in his shirt (2), and shrouded in three white Sahuli cloths not
foot_note:
1. There is question in this. Ibn al-Jawzi said in "Al-Mawdu'at" (199/ 1): Ibn al-Munadi said: All reports mentioning Al-Khidr are flimsy in beginning and end. They are one of two things: *Either inserted into some hadiths of late narrators by deception. *Or they belong to people who knew their status; narrated them out of wonder, then attributed to them as fact. He said: Most gullible people think Al-Khidr remains?! Eternity is not for a human, Allah - Mighty and Majestic - said: AND WE DID NOT GRANT TO ANY HUMAN BEFORE YOU ETERNITY [Al-Anbiya from verse:34]. He said in (200/ 1): Abu Bakr Al-Naqqash narrated: That Muhammad bin Ismail Al-Bukhari was asked about Al-Khidr and Elias, are they alive? He said: How can that be, when the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: «No one of those on the face of the earth will remain at the head of a hundred years»?! 
2. Imam Ahmad extracted in his "Musnad" (267/ 6) from Aisha - may Allah be pleased with her, said: «When they wanted to wash the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, they differed in it. They said: By Allah! We do not see how to act? Do we strip the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, as we strip our dead, or do we wash him with his clothes on? -

book_title: Al-Ghurar wa Al-Durar fi Sirat Khayr Al-Bashar (The Blazes and Pearls in the Biography of the Best of Mankind), may Allah bless him and grant him peace
text:
Containing a shirt (Qamis), nor a turban (1). His uncle Al-Abbas prayed over him, then Banu Hashim, then the Muhajirun, then the Ansar. Abu Talhah Al-Ansari made a niche (Lahd) in his grave and dug it (2). Nine bricks were placed over his niche (3).

40 - Duration of his illness, peace and blessings be upon him: Thirteen nights, and it was said: twelve nights (4). He died on Monday, two nights passed of Rabi' al-Awwal, and it was said: twelve passed of Rabi' al-Awwal when the forenoon intensified. This is preponderant according to Ibn Hazm and a group. It was said: beginning of Rabi' al-Awwal (5). The preponderant view with the majority: That it was twelve passed of Rabi' al-Awwal. There is question in it, and Allah knows best.
foot_note:
1. = She said: When they differed, Allah sent sleep upon them, until by Allah not a man of the people but his chin was on his chest sleeping. She said: Then someone spoke to them from the side of the house, they do not know who he is, saying: Wash the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, with his clothes on. She said: They rose to him, and washed the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, while he was in his shirt, pouring water and Sidr over him, and men rubbing him with the shirt. She used to say: If I had known earlier what I know now, none would have washed the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, except his wives». 
1. Extracted by Al-Bukhari (425/ 1), and Muslim (649/ 2). 
2. See: "Sunan Al-Tirmidhi" (365/ 3), and "Tabaqat Ibn Sa'd" (298/ 2). 
3. See: "Tabaqat Ibn Sa'd" (297/ 2 - 298). 
4. Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar said in "Fath al-Bari" (129/ 8): "They differed on the duration of his illness. Most say thirteen days. It was said more by a day, and said less". 
5. This is the opinion of Musa bin Uqbah, Al-Layth, and others, as transmitted by Al-Hafiz in "Al-Fath" (129/ 8).

book_title: Al-Ghurar wa Al-Durar fi Sirat Khayr Al-Bashar (The Blazes and Pearls in the Biography of the Best of Mankind), may Allah bless him and grant him peace
text:
And may Allah bless our master and mawla Muhammad and his family and companions and grant peace. And may Allah be pleased with the Companions, and the Kindred all together, and with the Followers, and the Followers of the Followers with goodness until the Day of Judgment. And our last call is that praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds.
